We gather here in Munich 600 miles from Ukraine border, the distance of Atlanta to DC. The Mayor of Kyiv came here pleading for help and reinforced that this was a time for our actions to rise to the level of our rhetoric about solidarity and reliability. 10/11

So often we frame the main contours of international clashes as one between democracies and autocracies. But the conversations here in Munich help show that the question of our time might be: will we stand up together to defend the rules-based system globally and at home. 9/11

We yearn for ‚Äúnormalcy‚Äù but what we often mean is that we want reliability. We want predictability. Solidarity breeds reliability and predictability and seeks to contain the unimaginable. Solidarity with other nations in a rules-based system is what hedges against anxiety. 8/11

RELIABILITY:  I can feel anxiety across the crowd in Munich. It has similarities to anxiety in my home district in NJ. Anxiety in both cases is rooted in unpredictability of our era. We live in a time when unimaginable is reality. Whether pandemic, Jan 6, war in Europe. 7/11

SOLIDARITY: Word everyone in Munich seems to be using to describe what is needed is solidarity. Whether in context of Ukraine, NATO, democratic states, or other arrangements. This focus on is critical. But I‚Äôve been asking what is it about solidarity that is so powerful? 6/11

German foreign minister echoed concerns of breakdown of order. She asks, Are we living in age of helplessness? We are not helpless, she concludes. We draw our strength from action. But how do we act in a way that fights against hopelessness? What does that actually mean? 5/11

BREAKDOWN OF ORDER: Many people here talk about ‚Äúbreakdown of order.‚Äù UN SecGen said Russia crisis is example of challenge we face when rules of global order are tossed aside. He said challenges of miscommunication and miscalculation are higher than ever in this environment. 4/11

The conference chair said this is in his opinion the most important gathering of MSC ever. It‚Äôs not just that crises have become more intense/numerous. He reiterated theme of apathy and need to ‚Äúunlearn helplessness‚Äù. What is creating this vivid sense of helplessness? 3/11

LET‚ÄôS UNLEARN HELPLESSNESS: These 3 words flashed on screen as conference opened. This intrigued me. In a room full of world leaders, it says something about magnitude of challenges we face that leaders need to guard against feeling overwhelmed and descending into apathy. 2/11

As I walk up streets of Germany today where world leaders gather for the Munich Security Conference during perilous time, it‚Äôs clear that Russia/Ukraine is first on agenda. But as I talk more with people here, I sense a deeper worry about the world is also on their minds.THREAD http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL99qNAXsAMuTGj.jpg

Zelenskyy powerfully connects Ukraine‚Äôs struggle to the interest of every nation interested in a rules-based order rooted in liberal values. @MunSecConf #munichsecurityconference http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL99cAbUYAUaled.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FL99cAcVUAM8A7N.jpg

I continue working to ensure this dark era is never forgotten. This Congress, I'm a proud co-sponsor of legislation to preserve confinement sites and to continue educating Americans, particularly young people, of the wrongful forced roundup of our fellow citizens.
It was my honor to attend the bill signing, which included my legislation to acknowledge this terrible wrong and provide compensation for Japanese Americans and the Alaska Natives from the Aleutians.

In 1988, I proudly helped pass the Civil Liberties Act. I worked hard to ensure it included comprehensive restitution for both Japanese Americans and the Alaska Natives who suffered at the hands of this egregious government policy.
For years, these innocent people were forced to live in poor conditions, often without clothes, plumbing, or electricity.

The grave injustice of internment reached Alaska as well. In 1942, hundreds of UnangaxÃÇ people from nine villages in the Aleutians were forced onto cramped transport ships as they watched their homes and churches set ablaze.
Interning our Japanese American neighbors was an evil act that not only deprived them of their life and property, but also their dignity.

Growing up, I remember attending local Farm Bureau meetings with my father. I will never forget how he courageously stood publicly against the Japanese American internment, repeatedly pointing out that these were our fellow citizens and friends.
